title: The other is the Emily incident which occurred in 1821. The Emily was an American merchant ship. Francis Terranova, a crew member on board, dropped an earthenware pot on the head of a Chinese woman in a boat below, and she fell into the river and drowned. The Chinese authority demanded Terranova’s surrender and when denied, threatened to stop all American trade in Canton. The man was subsequently surrendered, and he was executed the following day. See Jonathan Spence, The Search for Modern China

title: Inke Gunia is Professor of Spanish and Hispanoamerican Literature at the University of Hamburg, Germany. Her research interests include the relationship between factuality and fictionality, autobiographical and autofictional writing, the historical vanguards in Hispanoamerica, the counterculture of the 1960s and 1970s in Mexico, the artistic/literary field in Spain in the 18th and 19th centuries, and the literatures of Hispanoamerica of the 19th and 20th centuries. She is the author of La modernidad revis(it)ada: Literatura y cultura latinoamericanas de los siglos XIX y XX

title: Rotem Kowner is Professor of Japanese History and Culture at the University of Haifa, Israel. His research has focused on the contacts between Japan and the West since the early modern era, Japan’s modern wars, and Japanese attitudes to Jews. His recent works in these domains include the monograph From White to Yellow: The Japanese in European Racial Thought, 1300–1735

title: Lars Peter Laamann is Lecturer in history at the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, as well as editor of the Central Asiatic Journal. The author’s research interests focus on popular religion and healing in Qing and Republican China, as well as on the creation of the welfare ideal in modern China. A parallel field of research is Manchu studies, with the emphasis on the role of religion in Manchu/Qing society
